title: 110_hr2584
content: The Act titled "High-Need Physician Workforce Incentives Act of 2007" amends the Public Health Service Act to include a Scholarship Program for High-Need Physician Specialty Workforce Incentives. The section aims to address physician shortages in key medical fields through grants for scholarship programs at critical shortage health facilities. Recipients of the grants must provide scholarships to eligible individuals enrolled in medical schools for up to four years. The scholarship program requires recipients to maintain academic standing, complete a residency in specific medical fields, and serve as a physician at a designated facility for a period based on the years of scholarship received. The amount of scholarship paid to individuals is determined by the health facility. The scholarship amount for an individual is capped at $30,000 per school year. The health facility considers financial need, geographic differences, and educational costs when determining the scholarship amount. Any scholarship received is excluded from gross income. The program established under this section follows certain provisions similar to the National Health Service Corps Scholarship Program. The National Health Service Corps Scholarship Program defines critical shortage health facilities and eligible individuals. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. "SEC. 776. LOAN REPAYMENT PROGRAM." The purpose of this section is to address physician shortages in specific fields by establishing a loan repayment program for individuals who agree to serve in areas with critical physician shortages. The loan repayment program aims to address physician shortages by offering up to $35,000 annually towards the educational loans of individuals who agree to serve in underserved areas through various healthcare entities. The program follows similar provisions as the National Health Service Corps Loan Repayment Program. The Health Service Corps Loan Repayment Program, established in the subpart, defines an eligible individual as someone with a degree in medicine or osteopathic medicine. $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012. SEC. 777. PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN RETENTION AND MEDICAL HOME ENHANCEMENT GRANTS. The Secretary will make grants to States for care management fees to physicians in medically underserved areas to support targeted, accessible, continuous, coordinated, and patient-centered care through qualified medical homes. Qualified medical homes are physician-directed practices certified as such by designated external entities. The Secretary will make grants to States for care management fees to physicians in medically underserved areas to support targeted, accessible, continuous, coordinated, and patient-centered care through qualified medical homes. Requirements for certification include a voluntary application process and demonstration of capabilities for improving patient care management and coordination. The care management model described in paragraph (5) targets underserved, special needs, or high-risk patients who lack health insurance or are eligible for medical assistance under title XIX or child health assistance under title XXI of the Social Security Act. The care management model in paragraph (3)(B) utilizes health information technology and physician-practice innovations to enhance patient care coordination. It involves physicians advocating for optimal patient-centered outcomes, using evidence-based medicine, accepting accountability for quality improvement, and engaging in performance measurement. Patients actively participate in decision-making, take personal responsibility for their health, utilize information technology for optimal care, and engage in quality improvement activities. States must determine the amount of care management fees for grants. The Secretary will issue guidance for determining care management fees under the grant, considering implementation costs, physician time, and training for compliance. This includes recognizing the value of non-face-to-face patient care activities like educating caregivers and arranging follow-up services. The curr_chunk discusses arranging follow-up services with healthcare professionals, recognizing expenses for health information technology, additional performance-based reimbursement payments, reimbursement for e-mail and telephonic consultations, and recognizing specific circumstances. The curr_chunk discusses the application process for states seeking grants under this section, including the methodologies for determining care management fees and the authorization of appropriations for implementing qualified medical homes. Authorized $10,000,000 for fiscal years 2008 through 2012. SEC. 778. COMPREHENSIVE GERIATRIC TRAINING GRANTS. The Secretary will provide grants to board-certified entities to establish geriatric fellowship programs for physicians in rural areas or family practice, internal medicine, emergency medicine, general surgery, or obstetrics-gynecology. Each fellowship funded by the grant must be 1 year long, with a maximum expenditure of $50,000 per fellow. Preference will be given to programs in rural or suburban areas. To expand fellowship programs in rural, suburban, or medically underserved areas, $1,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012. The High-Need Physician Workforce Incentives Act of 2007 requires the Secretary to submit annual reports to Congress on grants and loans made to address physician workforce needs in rural areas and specialties like family practice, internal medicine, pediatrics, emergency medicine, general surgery, and obstetrics-gynecology. Additionally, there is an exemption from gross income for compensation paid to physicians by local governments for service in medically underserved areas. Section 139B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempts certain compensation paid to physicians by local governments for service in medically underserved areas. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempts physician compensation from local governments for qualified medical services in medically underserved areas. Compensation is excluded from gross income if the services are performed under a contract for at least 4 years. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 exempts physician compensation from local governments for qualified medical services in medically underserved areas, if the services are performed under a contract for at least 4 years. Additionally, compensation excluded from gross income under this section is listed in the table of sections for part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code exempts physician compensation from local governments for medical services in underserved areas under a 4-year contract. Section 139B specifies the compensation excluded from gross income. The amendments apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
